 COLOMBIA URBAN ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT PROJECT TECHNICAL ANNEX I. BACKGROUND A. Legal and Institutional Framework for Environmental Management in Urban Areas 1. Environmental Management 1. Colombia has a long tradition of environmental management and was one of the first countries in Latin America to adopt comprehensive environmental legislation. The C6digo de Recursos Naturales Renovablesy de Protecci6n al Medio Ambiente, adopted in 1973, established the country's basic environmental legal framework. The responsibility for implementing and enforcing the code was given to the Instituto Nacional de los Recursos Naturales Renovables y del Ambiente (INDERENA), which focused its environmental management on natural resources to the exclusion of urban environmental issues. A number of other national and regional agencies, however, carried out related activities, often resulting in unclear lines of authority and overlaps and gaps in responsibility. The regulatory framework for natural resource management and pollution control was similarly fragmented and had a poor enforcement record, either due to unrealistic standards, deficient monitoring or inappropriate institutional mechanisms. 2. The decade of the 1990s has seen a resurgence of interest in the environment in Colombia. The new constitution, adopted in 1991, explicitly recognizes the right of the citizens of Colombia to a healthy environment (Article 79) and identifies protection of the environment among the fundamental objectives of the State for maintaining the general welfare and improving the quality of life of the people (Article 366). Furthermore, in 1993, Colombia passed new environmental framework legislation, Law 99, establishing a comprehensive Sistema Nacional Ambiental (SINA) and creating the new Ministerio del Medio Ambiente (MinAmbiente) to head the SINA. As the focal point for environmental issues at the national level, MinAmbiente replaces INDERENA and exercises broad policy, planning, and regulatory authorities for management of natural resources, prevention and control of pollution, assessment of environmental impacts, and issuance of environmental licenses. In carrying out its mandate, MinAmbiente is called upon by Law 99 to work in close coordination with the National Planning Department (DNP), and with the Ministries of Economic Development, Health, and Education, as well as with other government agencies as needed.
 3. The newly-established SINA defines the overall framework for environmental management at the national, regional, and local levels of government in the country (see Figure 1). The decentralization of environmental management envisioned under this system will place increased responsibility for policy implementation and enforcement on the regional and local levels of government. At the regional level, the country's 34 Corporaciones Aut6nomas Regionales (CARs) will have to carry out most of the new environmental management functions specified in Title VI of Law 99 (e.g., implementing national policies, plans, and programs; issuing environmental licenses; setting regional environmental standards; monitoring and enforcing environmental requirements; and collecting environmental fees and taxes) under general guidance from MinAmbiente. At the departmental and municipal levels of government, a set of local environmental management functions complementary to those of the CARs are to be exercised. However, Law 99 gives special status to the major urban centers with populations of over one million inhabitants (i.e., Bogota, Medellin, Cali, and Barranquilla), which, assigned the same functions as the CARs, are to establish environmental institutions and undertake the environmental management functions within their jurisdictions. 4. As Figure 1 indicates, the SINA includes a number of other institutions with intersectoral coordination, scientific and technical, and oversight and enforcement functions. The Consejo Nacional Ambiental, which brings together governmental agencies (including the National Planning Department - DNP), scientific institutions, non-governmental organizations (NGOs), environmental experts and representatives of specific social groups, provides intersectoral coordination and advice on environmental policies, plans, and sectoral agendas. The Consejo Thcnico Asesor de Politica Ambiental, which is composed of academics and representatives of the industrial, agricultural, mining, and petroleum sectors, advises MinAmbiente on the environmental feasibility of major national projects, both public and private, on the formulation of national policies, and on the promulgation of environmental standards. To provide scientific and technical support, the SINA also includes five institutes, one of which, the Instituto de Hidrologia, Meteorologia y Estudios Ambientales (IDEAM), is the core agency of the National Environmental Information System (NEIS), as set forth in Decreto 1600 of 1994. Finally, several institutions carry out important oversight and enforcement functions: the Contraloria General, which monitors public expenditures on the environment by institutions of the SINA; the Procuraduria Delegada para Asuntos Ambientales, which ensures effective implementation of environmental provisions by the institutions of the SINA; and the Policia Ambiental, a special corps of the National Police which will assist SINA institutions in enforcing the requirements of the law. 5. MinAmbiente is in the process of preparing the regulations, standards, and procedures necessary to institutionalize the SINA and to fully implement and enforce the provisions of Law 99. For example, MinAmbiente has already promulgated the requirements and procedures for obtaining environmental licenses (Decreto 1753 of 1994). At this point, much of the national regulatory framework is in place, including regulations relating to: (i) air pollution from fixed and mobile sources; (ii) water quality, use and pollution; (iii) management of solid and hazardous waste (including imports); (iv) noise control; 2

Law 99 establishes a number of specific economic instruments to finance the new environmental institutions and activities of the SINA. As specified in Title VII of the Law, these include (i) charges for the use of the environment (i.e., air, water, and soil) as a sink for the discharge of pollution (tasas retributivas) and to compensate for the use of renewable natural resources (tasas compensatorias); (ii) charges for the use of water by public and private entities to pay for the protection and restoration of water resources; (iii) a choice between a percentage set-aside (i.e., 15 to 25.9 percent) of the revenues raised by local governments in property taxes (impuesto predial), or a surcharge on the property taxes (i.e. 1.5/1000 to 2.5/1000) based on property appraisal; (iv) the transfer from large-scale hydroelectric powers producers of a percentage (6 percent) of the gross receipts from their sales of electricity; and (v) a percentage of annual revenues from the Fondo Nacional de Regalias1. DNP has estimated that, through environmental charges and fees, approximately US$ 264 million will be made available to the country's four major urban areas during the 1995-98 period. Detailed regulation for use of such instruments is, however, still pending. In addition, Title XIII of Law 99 created two special environmental funds: the Fondo Nacional Ambiental (FONAM) and the Fondo Ambiental de la Amazonia. The FONAM is a special account established within MinAmbiente to support national, regional and local implementation of environmental management policies, programs and activities, management of natural resources (including national parks), institutional strengthening, and environmental education. The FONAM's resources are derived from government appropriations, donations, loans, and other specified sources. The Amazonian environmental fund is also a special account established within MinAmbiente. It is designed to channel international technical and financial assistance for the execution of environmental policies and projects in the Colombian Amazon. 7. Public participation in environmental management is guaranteed in Colombia through a number of sectoral laws, as well as in Law 99 and the Constitution of 1991. Among other things, Title X of Law 99 provides the public (i) the right to participate in the administrative processes for issuing, modifying, or revoking environmental licenses and for imposing sanctions for violations of environmental standards and (ii) the right, under certain conditions, to a public hearing before the appropriate administrative authority concerning the issuance of an environmental license. The latter was used, for example, to hold a public hearing on the proposed runway for the El Dorado Airport in Bogota. Under related legal provisions, the public may seek information on activities likely to cause pollution or threaten human health. ' The Fondo Nacional de Regalias is based on royalties paid by the petroleum, natural gas, and mining industries for the extraction of non-renewable natural resources which are defined as national property. Total annual revenues of the fund are estimated at between US$ 140-150 million. Of these, 20% are set aside for natural resource management and environmental protection activities. 4
 8. Because the right to a healthy environment is guaranteed in the Constitution of 1991, the general provisions contained in the Constitution to protect fundamental rights also apply to protection of the environment. For example, under Article 86 of the Constitution, citizens have the right, as a last resort, to initiate a legal action (acci6n de tutela) before a judge for the protection of their constitutional rights when such rights are threatened by the action or omission of any public authority. The acci6n de tutela was first used in 1992 in the city of Buga to address health and environmental threats posed by an asphalt plant. Since then, a number of other such cases have been brought by citizens for the defense of the environment. Additionally, Article 87 grants citizens the right to bring a legal action (acci6n de cumplimiento) against any public authority to secure full and effective compliance with any law or administrative act. Furthermore, under Article 88, citizens may bring legal actions (acciones populares) to protect their collective constitutional rights, including those pertaining to the environment. 9. Colombia has a large and active environmental NGO community, some 260 of which are joined with 27 governmental institutions under the umbrella organization ECOFONDO. Established in 1993, ECOFONDO functions both as a network of environmental organizations and as a private trust fund allocating resources for solving environmental problems. ECOFONDO's financial resources come from grants from national and international organizations and from funds generated by debt restructuring mechanisms agreed to by creditor nations. The latter is expected to provide ECOFONDO with US$ 53 million between 1993 and 2002 from the US and Canada. These funds will be allocated to a number of NGO projects, including environmental education, watershed management, and environmental management in urban areas. 2. Urban Management 10. Urban management in Colombia has recently undergone several important changes. In the late 1980s, Colombia set in motion a process of decentralization which included the transfer of administrative responsibilities from the national to the local level of government, the establishment of national revenue sharing, and the democratic election of mayors and district administrative councils. In addition, the Constitution of 1991 further encouraged transparency and accountability in urban administration. The Colombian citizenry has responded well to these changes, revealing new capacities for local management and govemance and supporting continued decentralization of governmental responsibilities. 11. Law 152 of 1994 authorizes the establishment of special districts and metropolitan areas and defines procedures for development planning at the regional and local levels. The cities of Bogota, the national capital, and Barranquilla have been designated special districts; Medellin and nine surrounding municipalities have been designated a metropolitan area. Cali continues to operate as an independent municipality. Neither the limits of the districts of Bogota and Barranquilla nor those of the municipality of Cali comprise however the continuous urbanized area of these cities, which in effect extend into the municipalities of Soacha, Soledad, and Yumbo, respectively. Since a significant part of the pollution which 5
 affects the residents of Bogota, Cali and Barranquilla originates in industries located in the neighboring municipalities, environmental planning and pollution control will require effective coordination mechanisms between the EMAs and the relevant CARs. Similar coordination is needed to address air pollution problems associated with the transportation sector. 12. The planning process for Colombian cities, as defined by Law 152, is carried out every three years in a six-month exercise, leading to the adoption of a three-year municipal development plan. Typically, local plans are developed through a broad-based participatory process culminating in approval by the Municipal Council. Each plan includes a three-year investment program which forms the basis for annual budgets. Planning activities and studies to be carried out during the coming three-year period should be contemplated in the three- year investment program and plan. 13. Community participation and public involvement in urban management is guaranteed through both planning and oversight mechanisms. Law 152 established consultations with "territorial planning councils", which represent diverse stakeholders, NGOs and community leaders as part of planning procedures for municipalities. Building on a long tradition of neighborhood action, the Juntas Administradoras Locales, democratically elected neighborhood and district organizations, were given legal status in 1986. These Juntas submit proposals for the municipal development plans, and are, in many cases, co-financiers and implementing agents of programs defined in the plans. Public oversight of municipal management is made effective mostly through individual legal actions defined by the Constitution. Through acciones de cumplimiento, officials are held accountable for fulfilling campaign promises as spelled out in a "political program". According to Law 99, veedurias ciudadanas and acciones de lutela offer citizens legal grounds and procedures on which to request a public hearing, to petition and eventually enjoin any public or private sector activity or decision which may cause adverse impact on the environment. 14. The process of decentralizing administrative responsibilities has been accompanied by a parallel effort to both increase local opportunities for generating income and simplify access to sources of financing for cities, by unifying eligibility requirements and criteria. While secondary cities still depend on revenue sharing from national and departmental government budget transfers for some 80 percent of local income, the four largest cities successfully raise over half of their income from local tax sources. All cities can borrow from private lenders, but the largest source of investment capital is FINDETER, a discounting mechanism which allows national funds to be channeled through commercial banks. FINDETER was established in 1989 to finance local works relating to water, sanitation, infrastructure, public works, education, and health. Its mandate has since been broadened to include works for environmental mitigation and prevention. Since FINDETER can cover only part of a project's investment costs and no up-front costs of project preparation (e.g. feasibility studies), cities frequently seek additional resources from any of several co-financing funds available on a matching grants basis (e.g., the Social Investment Fund-FIS, the Fund for Urban Infrastructure-INURBE). 6
 B. Policy Framework 1. The National Environmental Policy 15. The National Development Plan (El Salto Social) prepared by the Samper administration devotes a chapter to promoting sustainable human development, in which the key environmental priorities of the National Government for the 1994-1998 period are identified. These priority programs are: (i) preservation of strategic ecosystems, (ii) improved management of water resources, (iii) restoration of marine and coastal systems, (iv) expansion of protected forest areas, (v) improved environmental management in urban areas, and (vi) cleaner technology for industrial production. 16. The National Council for Economic and Social Policy (CONPES) approved in December 1994 Colombia's National Environmental Policy (CONPES Document no. 2750), which provides general guidelines for the priority environmental programs defined in the National Development Plan. The policy recognizes the special environmental problems which affect many of the country's urban areas, resulting in unsustainable patterns of growth, exacerbating conditions of poverty and disease, deteriorating the quality of life, and often driving the population to occupy areas of high risk or of great agricultural value. The quality of the surface waters near urban areas has deteriorated significantly in recent years because of uncontrolled discharges. Less than five percent of Colombian cities treat their wastewater before discharging them to surface waters. The inadequate management and disposal of solid and hazardous wastes contribute to the spread of infectious disease vectors and adversely affect public health, particularly of the poorest residents in marginal neighborhoods. The urban transport situation in the largest cities is dramatic and significantly affects the quality of life of their inhabitants, due particularly to the resulting air pollution and noise levels. The inefficient management, increasing loss, and general degradation of urban public spaces also impact negatively on the quality of urban life. 17. The objective of the urban environmental management program (Programa Mejores Ciudades) is to improve the quality of life and health of Colombians who live in urban areas, reducing urban pollution, rationalizing public transportation, and restoring public parks and open spaces. Fundamental to this effort is the creation and development of environmental institutions in the major urban centers. Under this program, MinAmbiente has committed to assisting urban areas in the development of integrated environmental policies and programs, including appropriate regulatory and economic instruments, and to supporting the preparation and implementation of Environmental Action Plans in the largest cities and urban centers. To this end, minimum national standards for environmental protection are being established, and will need to be monitored and enforced. Programs for the substitution of less-polluting fuels and the management of solid and liquid wastes will be developed, and economic incentives for pollution control will be put in place. Decentralized implementation, with strong public participation, reliance on the market, and partnerships with the private sector where possible are encouraged. In addition, the Government of Colombia will underwrite and co-finance certain environmental restoration projects in urban areas. -7
 2. The National Urban Policy 18. In addition to its focus on human sustainable development, the National Development Plan also defines priority actions in other key areas relating to urban issues: habitat, governability, decentralization and regional development, and participation and civil society. 19. With respect to habitat, the plan defines three priority issues: (i) overcrowding and precarious housing conditions; (ii) inadequate social infrastructure; and (iii) insufficient coverage of public services. For the latter, it proposes the multisectoral Plan de Aguas with goals of 90 percent coverage in water and 77 percent in sanitation by 1998, modernization of the sector and improved water quality. While the first three goals will be addressed through directed financing from FINDETER, the Fund for Urban Infrastructure, and others, MinAmbiente is expected to offer technical and financial assistance to the four largest cities under a program to optimize resources, protect sources of potable water and specifically to reduce pollution in reservoirs and other bodies of water into which wastewater is discharged. MinAmbiente will also collaborate with the National Institute of Geology and Mines (INGEOMINAS) for the exploration and rationalization of water sources. 20. With respect to decentralization and regional development, the national policy framework emphasizes the importance of "consensus and citizen participation to increase social capital" throughout the processes of program planning and management, control and evaluation. Continued commitment to decentralization is to be achieved by strengthening the management capacities of local institutions, both governmental and non-governmental, and by streamlining and strengthening the system of regional financing and increasing the sources of funds. One of MinAmbiente's tasks is to assist in the development of the environmental agencies in the largest cities, including the preparation of environmental action plans. In addition, the National Government expressly offers to guarantee financing or co-financing for priority environmental programs, such as management of hazardous and hospital wastes, and decontamination of fuels. 21. Under citizen participation and civil society, the National Government commits to strengthening the role of NGOs in governance and to creating a special fund for citizen participation. The fund, as specified in Law 134 of 1994, would co-finance research and activities oriented towards increasing citizen participation carried out by universities, NGOs and private organizations. The importance given to stakeholders and to non-governmental advisors in the planning process is reflected in the creation of ECOFONDO, described above. C. Strategy for Strengthening the SINA 22. Colombia has made impressive progress in the past few years in redesigning its legal and institutional framework for environmental management. Since the enactment of Law 99, regulations have been adopted on environmental licensing and air emission standards for fixed and mobile sources. A National Environmental Policy has been prepared and is one of the 8
 four major priorities of the Samper Administration's National Development Plan. Although created in December 1993, MinAmbiente only began operating in mid-1994 but has since then made substantial progress in creating or strengthening the national, regional, and municipal institutions that make up the SINA: establishing the five Scientific Research Institutes, developing the National Environmental Information System (NEIS), and strengthening the CARs and EMAs directly in charge of environmental management in the different regions and major urban centers of the country. In some cases, institutions are being built up anew; in most, however, the SINA is drawing on existing structures and staff (for instance, from the existing and former CARs and the now defunct INDERENA). Substantial redesign, however, is being undertaken even in these cases. Major constraints and challenges to be faced by these agencies in the near-term include: (a) the clear definition of their mandate and division of responsibilities with other environment-related agencies (including those in the urban infrastructure sector), at the local, regional and national levels; (b) preparation of technical guidelines (e.g., terms of reference for licensing projects) and operating procedures (e.g., for enforcement of appropriate standards and agreed-upon measures by both the public and private sectors); (c) staffing in appropriate numbers and qualification; (d) availability of office facilities, monitoring and laboratory equipment; and (e) sufficient funding to carry out mandated activities. 23. Environmental agencies, at the national, regional or local levels will all face competing demands from the private sector (e.g., oil and power companies, consulting firms) and the educational sector (e.g., universities) for environmental specialists. Fortunately the civil service in Colombia is fairly competitive in terms of remuneration, benefits, and terms and conditions of employment, so these institutions should be able to attract and retain qualified university graduates. However, this will vary among the various institutions. MinAmbiente is in the strongest position, being at the national level, and is already filling its key positions with experienced professionals. Disparities can be expected among the urban institutions, however, where each has its own pay scale and municipal civil service tradition. The public sector in certain urban centers (e.g., Medellin and Cali) has a reputation for excellence and should have no trouble competing with the private sector. Furthermore, the environmental arena is seen as an attractive and expanding career field, one where public service can be a useful stepping stone to a more lucrative career in the private sector. 24. MinAmbiente currently has at its disposal projects with both the World Bank (i.e., the Natural Resource Management Project, Ln. 3692, FY94, and the Industrial Restructuring Project, Ln. 3321, FY91)) and the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) to support its institution building efforts. The Bank's Natural Resource Management Project (US$ 85 million total project cost) is assisting MinAmbiente with developing a National Forest Policy and supporting selected CARs in watershed rehabilitation and parks management. The Industrial Restructuring Project (US$ 200 million) has, through one of its components, provided technical assistance to revise and expand the regulatory framework, focusing especially on ambient quality and emissions standards, and to develop a proposal for the creation of an environmental monitoring network and a system of reference laboratories. The IDB's Environmental Management Program (US$ 125 million), approved in the beginning of 1995, has an institutional strengthening component (including training and environmental 9

DAHP is responsible for providing policy guidance and technical support to the different regional, departmental and municipal institutions in charge of environmental management in the urban areas of Colombia. MinAmbiente's strategy to improve environmental management in Colombian cities in the coming years focuses on institutional strengthening, taking into account the distinct 10

It is estimated that about half a million people in the city are directly exposed to these waters, and in some downstream municipalities, this contaminated water is used for crop irrigation. 32. It will provide support to MinAmbiente and the EMAs of the country's four largest cities in their initial 37
 stages of operation, assisting them to define appropriate organizational structures and mechanisms of collaboration with other public agencies, neighboring jurisdictions, local communities and the private sector, to address their new or expanded mandates.  Annex 3.1 Terms of Reference for Urban Environmental Strategies and Action Plans Background: Urban Environmental Action Plans (UEAPs) help to define environmental goals for the short, medium and long-term, as well as priority urban investments. In addition, they help to identify concrete actions relating to institutional strengthening and legal, regulatory and institutional reform which are necessary for effective and efficient urban environmental management. UEAPs are developed on the basis of forums, seminars, meetings and other forms of interaction between interested parties from the public and private sectors. Objective: The UEAPs to be financed under the Project would serve to orient urban management, identifying critical environmental problems and defining a staged strategy to address these. They would also propose priority environmental projects and programs, assigning specific responsibilities to public entities, and defining appropriate timeframes and budgets for their implementation. They would also help to orient the environmental activities and responsibilities of the private sector. Tasks: In accordance with the extensive international experience accumulated in preparation of UEAPs, the process to be followed during the preparation of such plans under the Urban Environmental Management Project would consist of the following activities: 1. Identification or establishment of appropriate coordination and participatory consultative mechanisms, comprising: (a) a high-level Advisory Committee, responsible for (i) overall supervision of preparation of the UEAP, (ii) obtaining its approval by the appropriate authorities, (iii) guaranteeing the allocation of necessary resources to carry out the UEAP, and (iv) following through its implementation; (b) Technical Working Groups, made up of representatives of the relevant municipal and sectoral entities, to discuss each priority environmental problem and to assist consultants in preparation of terms of reference for priority pre-investment studies (and subsequently follow through their preparation, as indicated in Annex 3.2); and (c) public participation mechanisms (e.g. local or regional environmental councils, round tables, town meetings) to stimulate a wide debate on priority environmental problems and their respective solutions and to obtain public consensus on these. 2. Execution of a rapid urban environmental assessment, based on secondary sources of information in order to develop a reliable data base of the environmental situation of the city in question, using as a tool, for example, the questionnaire developed by the Urban 51
 Management Program of the World Bank. This activity would utilize appropriate public participation mechanisms identified in Activity 1, such as interviews, round tables, and discussion with groups affected by a given environmental problem. 3. Preparation of an environmental profile for the city concerned, using the urban environmental data gathered through the rapid urban environmental assessment, together with descriptions and complementary explanations in order to obtain a better understanding of the environmental problems detected. 4. General discussion of the profile, in order to inform the public of the findings, and to stimulate dialogue, through, for example, a Town Meeting. At a minimum, the following would be consulted: (a) those affected by the priority environmental problems or by the actions required to resolve these problems; (b) those who would take the decision or manage the necessary resources and instruments in order to resolve the priority problems; and (c) those that possess the knowledge and information to resolve the problems. 5. Preparation of preliminary UEAP proposals, specifying medium and long-term goals in environmental management for the urban area and formulating a staged, comprehensive strategy to address current and emerging issues, based on the conclusions of the profile and the agreements obtained through the consultative process. The preliminary UEAP should also include summary terms of reference (TORs) for the projects and programs to be undertaken in the course of the next three years. Possible priority projects and programs would comprise: pollution abatement/control or natural resource management investment projects; legal and regulatory reforms; institutional reform; training and environmental education; monitoring and evaluation of er.mironmental conditions. 6. General discussion of the UEAP proposals with the public. 7. Adjustment and detailed formulation of the plan, incorporating recommendations from the discussion of the preliminary draft and developing the TORs for all proposed activities, specifying the institutional arrangements, coordination mechanisms, financial requirements, sources of funding, timetables, and monitoring and evaluation arrangements needed to carry out such projects and programs. 8. Submission of the plan to the approval of the appropriate local authorities. The UEAP would also be submitted to the Bank for consideration of the priority projects and programs which would be financed in subsequent years by the Project. Timeframe: 6-12 months 52

Such studies may result either from recommendations of the UEMNP (see Annex 3.1) or from discussions held with the Bank during project preparation. In the latter case specific terms of reference (TORs) for studies to be carried out during the first year are available in the project files. Objectives: Pre-feasibility studies would be carried out under the Project to (a) identify alternative solutions and define cost-effective options to solve clearly identified priority problems needing immediate attention to either mitigate or avoid fuirther damage to the urban environment. In addition, the Project would also finance studies to (b) define the medium- and long-term strategy with regard to emerging environmental problems identified in the UEMNP process, to develop preventive measures, emphasizing legal reform and institutional priorities, which in turn could lead to additional studies, for example, on new institutional arrangements, or the design of economic instruments. Tasks: The preparation of each study would comprise the following activities: 1. Review of the TORs by the Technical Working Groups established during the UEMP stage. 2. The execution of studies with the support of consultants, under the general supervision of the appropriate Technical Working Group. 3. The review and approval of the completed studies by the appropriate groups, and through a consultative process similar to that employed during the preparation of the UEMP. 4. The gathering of political support and confirmation of respective political decisions in order to guarantee the recommended course of action identified to resolve the environmental problem. Timeframe: Although this may vary considerably from study to study, it is expected that each study would take from 9 to 12 months on average. Budget: Budgets will vary for each study.  Annex 3.3 Terms of Reference for Studies and Seminars on Environmental Economics Background: Ley 99 of 1993 recognizes the importance of economic instruments in the new environmental policy of Colombia, providing sources of revenue for environmental management at the municipal and regional levels and establishing environmental fees (tasas retributivasy compensatorias) for the use of natural resources and contamination of the environment. In effect, these provisions make municipal and regional environmental management agencies (EMAs) environmental-economic planners. To support these agencies in these new functions, the project will finance technical assistance, specifically studies and seminars, with respect to the design and implementation of economic instruments for environmental management. Objective: The objective of the technical assistance is to support MinAmbiente and the EMAs of the four urban centers in establishing and putting into use appropriate economic instruments for urban environmental management. Activities: The technical assistance will include the following activities, which will take place in the first two years of the project. 1. Activities to be carried out by NinAmbiente during the first year of project implementation: (a) Study 1: Review of Existing Economic-Financial Instruments and Laws -- Inventory those instruments and laws in effect which may have to be changed as a result of Ley 99. Determine the legal and financial bases of national and local agencies to support environmental management. (duration: 3 months) (b) Study 2: Definition of Environmental Fees -- Provide the technizal basis for promulgation of tasas retributivasy compensatorias and the processes for their application and annual review/revision. (duration: 6 months) (c) Study 3: Additional Economic Instruments for Urban Environmental Management -- Review experience with a wide range of economic instruments in other countries. On the basis of specific environmental problems to be addressed by urban areas, it would provide a menu of economic instrument options for local implementation. (duration: 6 months) (d) Study 4: Economic-Financial Manual for Urban Environmental Management -- Prepare a manual of economic-financial instruments available to local authorities for environmental management, explaining 55

(duration: 3 months) (e) Seminar 1: International Seminar on Economic Instruments and Economic Valuation in Environmental Management. Review and discuss the study prepared for promulgation of the environmental fees. Agree on final draft of decree for fees.  Annex 3.6 Terms of Reference for Environmental Education Programs Background: As part of the institution building under the project, the environmental agencies in the four urban centers (i.e., DAMA, DAGMA, AREA, DADIMA) will each undertake a public awareness and environmental education program, both to raise public consciousness on urban environmental issues in general and to address priority urban environmental concerns in particular. This program will be developed in close coordination with the Ministerio de Educaci6n at the national level and with the appropriate educational institutions at the regional and local levels, and it will complement and build on the environmental management training program being developed by DAHP under the project. The following are generic terms of reference for the development of four-year Public Awareness and Environmental Education Programs under Component 2 of the Urban Environmental Management Project. Each urban center has provided specific terms of reference in its technical assistance proposal. Objective: The objective is to raise public consciousness and promote public involvement in urban environmental management through education by means of the communications media, formal education programs, and other related activities. Tasks: The public awareness and environmental education program would be developed in the following steps: (a) Assessment of existing public awareness/environmental education efforts. DAHP's Subdirecci6n de Educaci6n Ambiental has put in place an extensive environmental education program for the last half of 1995, involving the mass media, formal education programs, training, and other activities. In addition, Bogota's DAMA already has an environmental education program, which includes television messages, printed materials, and formal education programs in selected primary and secondary schools. The first step under the project will be to assess these ongoing efforts to determine exactly what is already being done, what has proven to be effective, and where additional efforts remain to be made. (b) Identification of public awareness/environmental education priorities. Based on the preliminary assessment of existing educational efforts and the consideration of priority urban environmental issues, the next step will be to identify priorities for the public awareness/environmental education program to be developed under the project, distinguishing among the various publics or target groups. This will vary from urban center to urban center depending on the status of existing educational efforts and the environmental priorities identified under the Urban Environmental Action Plan exercise. Thus, each urban center's four-year environmental educational program should be 64
 designed to address the particular environmental priorities identified in the urban area. (c) Design of an appropriate public awareness/environmental education program. The next step will be to develop an educational program, employing the range of public awareness/educational tools available, to address the priorities identified. The program will vary from urban center to urban center but should include (i) the mass media (i.e., television, radio, publications, printed materials, etc.); (ii) formal education programs (e.g., primary and secondary school curriculum, adult education, etc.); (iii) other educational and cultural activities (e.g., public forums, art exhibitions, festivals, etc.). The program will comprise the participating institutions, implementation timeframe, and the budget for the educational activities. The program should be designed with the active participation of non-governmental organizations (NGOs) and community-based groups with interest or experience in urban environmental issues. (d) Participation of NGOs and community organizations in the educational progra . Just as appropriate NGOs and other groups should participate in the design of the public awareness and educational program, they should have a significant role in implementation of the program as well. Through local networks and direct community involvement, they can be particularly effective in raising public consciousness for addressing issues of concern. ECOFONDO, through its membership of some 260 environmental NGOs, should be helpful in identifying effective community organizations for this purpose.  Annex 3.7 Terms of Reference for Urban Environmental Information Systems and Environmental Monitoring and Evaluation Systems Background: Under Colombia's Law 99, the Environmental Management Agencies (EMAs) of cities greater than one million inhabitants are responsible for establishing and operating an Environmental Information System within their area of jurisdiction, according to the directions and guidelines provided by MinAmbiente and IDEAM. Objective: Under the Urban Environmental Management Project, such an Urban Environmental Information System (UEIS) would be established by each of the EMAs to manage and share environmental information, operating in association with an Environmental Monitoring and Evaluation System (EMES), which would be used for monitoring compliance with standards, assessing the state of the environment, and providing inputs to decisionmakers involved in the the preparation and implementation of urban development and environmental management strategies. The UEIS would include a component for-the purposes of supporting the administrative functions of the EMA. Scope and Tasks: This activity would involve the setting up of four systems, each requiring a number of different steps, as detailed below. 1. Information System for the Support of the EMA's Administrative Functions: This system would facilitate the carrying out of the EMA's routine activities such as planning, programmimg and budgeting, personnel administration, financial management and accounting. Key activities in development of the system would be: a) Evaluation of support needed for the carrying out of the EMA's administrative processes b) Identification of system requirements based on the EMA' s technical and administrative functions and processes c) Evaluation of the software options and development of applications to meet the requirements identified in (b) d) Physical and logical design of the system e) Setting-up and test of the system f) Training of personnel in the use of the system 2. Information System for the Administration of Economic Instruments for Environmental Management: This system would facilitate the application by the EMA (or the local administration) of the economic instruments defined by Law 99 as incentives and sources of finance for environmental management. Its design can thus only be undertaken after the national and local regulations become available which will regulate the use of such economic instruments for environmental and specify the technical guidelines for their application. Key activities in development of this system would be: 66
 a) Documentation of international experience for estimation and administration of economic instruments b) Design or adaptation of models for: (i) the calculation of taxes, (ii) methods of billing, and (iii) payment procedures c) Physical and logical design of the system, including an intelligent user-friendly component accessible to the public d) Setting-up and test of the system e) Training of personnel in the use of the system f) Dissemination and orientation to the public g) Training of a sample of users 3. Information System for Licensing and Enforcement of Environmental Regulations: This system would facilitate the carrying out of the EMA's licensing and enforcement functions, by providing easily accessible references on relevant processing procedures, technical guidelines (e.g., typical TORs) and emission and ambient standards, as well as a computerized framework for the processing of licenses and following through on compliance with agreed-upon action plans. Design of this system depends on the previous definition, operationalization and enforcement of environmental regulations. It would be articulated with the Monitoring and Evaluation System (described in 4 below), from which it would receive information (e.g., on emission levels by industries) and with the Information System for the Administration of Economic Instruments for Environmental Management (described in 2 above), to which it would provide information on pollution fees, licensing fees and other funds generated by the application of the economic instruments specified in Law 99 . Key activities to be carried out would comprise: a) Identification of system requirements (e.g., licensing procedures) b) Evaluation of methods currently in use to collect, process, report and store information relative to the appropriate application of environmental regulations in licensing activities and pollution control c) Physical and logical design of the system, including an intelligent user-friendly component accessible to the public d) Setting-up and test of the system e) Training of personnel in the use of the system f) Dissemination and orientation to the public g) Training of a sample of users 4. Environmental Monitoring and Evaluation System: This system would generate, and process information relating to water, air, land and other aspects of environmental safety, and would assess and report on the state of the urban environment. It would be designed and set up in such a way as to facilitate access to indicators of the state of the environment, the preparation of projections, the design of control strategies and programs, the licensing of activities, and the application of analytical models integrating urban, economic and social variables. Design and operation of the system would be based on a network of institutions 67
 responsible for producing and using information relative to the state of the urban environment, under the general coordination of the EMA. Key activities would comprise: a) Definition of a basic conceptual model for indicator design b) Definition of: (i) the users of the measurements to be produced; (ii) the types of measurements needed for improved environmental management in the urban area; (iii) the recommended sampling points, frequency and measurement procedures; (iv) the analytical models to be used in generating environmental information; (v) the quality assurance procedures to be employed; and (vi) the interface between intitutions and sub-systems which generate and process information, assess and report on environmental conditions c) Evaluation of existing monitoring systems, the measurements produced, and their compatibility and adaptability to the needs defined above d) Identification of: (i) complementary measurement and indicator development requirements; (ii) the network of institutions which would be involved in monitoring, evaluating and disseminating environmental information; and (iii) a strategy to develop, within the network of urban institutions, the required capacity to carry out these activities e) Design of the logical structure of the information system required to process the information produced by the monitoring system, specifying sub-system modules and information flows f) Specification of: (i) the content and structure of each sub-system's data base; (ii) procedures for gathering, transmitting, analyzing, and disseminating information on levels of ambient quality and emissions from contaminating sources; (iii) the reports and other outputs of the system; and (iv) the types of access, protection and connections between different information systems and institutions which either provide or use environmental information g) Specification of: (i) the necessary software, hardware, measurement and laboratory facilities and equipment; (ii) the human resources required to operate the system (for instance, monitoring teams); (iii) training needs; (iv) the institutional and organizational structure needed to manage the system; and (v) the financial requirements for the operation of the system h) Setting-up and test of the sub-system components i) Training of personnel in measuring environmental quality and emissions, handling information, and other aspects related to the operation of the Monitoring and Evaluation System Institutional arrangements: The design of the UEIS and the EMES would be undertaken by each EMA with the support of consultants and in close collaboration with MinAmbiente and IDEAM. Two institutional mechanisms are envisaged to support this activity: a) a Local Steering Committee, made up of representatives of key public agencies, research centers and laboratories which are already relevant in generating or using 68
 information on the state of the environment or would be likely to participate in the institutional network which would operate the proposed systems in the future; and b) a Technical Working Group, established under the leadership of MinAmbiente and IDEAM, with representation from the four urban centers, which (i) would allow the exchange of experiences among the various cities; and (ii) would be responsible for ensuring the necessary coordination and consistency in UEISs across the various urban areas, as well as with IDEAM's and MinAmbiente's guidelines with respect to the development and operation of environmental information systems Sequence of Activities: The design of the UEIS and the EMES would be undertaken by each EMA in accordance with the following sequence of activities: a) Establishment of the coordination mechanisms at the local level and with MinAmbiente and IDEAM (and other regional and national agencies as needed) (see above) b) Preparation by each city, with the support of the local Steering Committee, of a general proposal for the configuration of its UEIS and EMES and its linkages to the National Environmental Information System c) Approval of the general proposals by the Technical Working Group d) Formulation, by each city, with the support of the Steering Committee, of a general strategy for design and implementation of its UEIS and EMES, taking into account: (i) management and information requirements defined in the UEMP (preliminary results); and (ii) the minimal compatibility requirements identified by the Technical Working Group e) Approval of the general strategies by the Technical Working Group f) Detailed design of the UEIS components and the EMES including training programs and schedules for the acquisition of equipment g) Review by the Technical Working Group of the annual work plans for strengthening environmental monitoring capacity in the four cities and all other proposals relating to the establishment or improvement of urban environmental information systems, prior to the submission of such plans to the Project Steering Committee described in para. 80 of the Technical Annex. Timeframe: Activity a would take place prior to loan effectiveness. Activities b through_ above would be carried out during the first year of project implementation. Detailed design of the UEIS components and of the EMES would take place in the following years, in accordance with each city's general strategy, as defined in d above and approved by the technical Working Group. Budget: The budget for this activity varies for each of the EMAs, due to the different state of readiness and existing framework in each of the cities. doc.abstracts: The primary objective of the Urban Environmental Management Project is to support implementation of Colombia's National Environmental Policy and the improvement of environmental management capacity in the country's urban areas through: 1) strengthening MinAmbiente's capacity to provide policy advice and technical assistance to Colombian cities; and 2) strengthening environmental management agencies (EMAs) in the urban centers of Bogota, Cali, Medellin, and Barranquilla. In support of this primary objective, the project will also help establish those components of the National Environmental Information System (NEIS), both at the national and local levels, which are instrumental to the improvement of urban environmental management. The technical assistance project will consist of two components: 1) design and implementation of a technical assistance strategy through MinAmbiente/Directorate of Human Settlements and Population in MinAmbiente (DAHP) for cities of less than one million inhabitants; and 2) institutional strengthening of the EMAs of the country's four main urban centers.
